ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a tremendous amount about Polish Jews in the interwar period and just learned how to be better reader and writer of history
I learned a very thorough history of the Jews in Interwar Poland as well as all of the moving political pieces of the era. I also became a much better writer because of the excellent feedback.

This class provides such an in-depth portrait of Jewish life, politics, and Polish-Jewish relations in the interwar period. It is one of the most challenging and complex topics in Jewish history, and the class forces you and teaches you to do intensive historical analysis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved the course. The workload was a lot but incredibly meaningful.

The class is really dense, which is in turn a strength and potentially a weakness. Most of the weeks are very manageable for reading and workload, but a few of the weeks on politics do get bogged down in the density of the material.  Still, the class is really able to come out of that and Karolina does a fantastic job of balancing  keeping track of the many moving pieces of the picture with letting some of the details fly by to work towards a deeper understanding of the themes and dynamics. The class is incredibly laid out balancing politics with culture, and really nearly perfect the way it is.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought it went very smoothly. My teacher essentially just facilitated conversation, wed have cameras on but mics off

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes absolutely. Karolina was absolutely brilliant and amazing. The class is so fascinating you learn so much and she makes it an incredibly warm and lively environment.

I would definitely recommend this class to anyone. It's very accessible even though it covers a very specific period, and Karolina is an amazing teacher who explains complex things so well. Hands down my favorite class so far (I'm a Junior).

YES!! It's a difficult course so if you don't have a good bit of energy to put into it, be warned. But it's also incredibly rewarding and might be the single course where I have learned the most at Yale. The topic is so fascinating and so important yet underrated in history (the Holocaust itself receiving, understandably, much more attention) and absolutely one that more people should learn. The readings can be dense, but they're all fascinating (and some even fun!).  An excellent, excellent course. Take it.
